Message.Title: Because Kenny Sold - Isn't Really A Sound Reason to Go Short
Message.Msg: i hope shorty thought it through more than that

It's like being caught long in a draw down. You have to either bite the bullet and cover OR short more higher and hope for a dip to cover. Averaging Up.......It does look like this stock is exhausted been quite a run......

I suspect averaging up has been the norm for the past fewl weeks. i just dont think kenny is with the shorts any longer. he's not going to give them the dump of shares that gets them out quietly. i guess the shorts are counting on a crummy quarter. not sure even that will do it for them.

I think most importantly, LLF is not sitting on the BOD for this quarter's earnings. Therefore, no "sneak peak" prior to the release. I suspect that is where most of the money has been made here. Probably done in some sort of code speak. Blue horseshoe hates etfc......
U.S. June budget surplus $117 billion: Treasury

What are you talking about. There are more people on food stamps assistance than in the work force. 17+ trillion in debt, half the new hires are part time...and Bernanke says the economy can't stand on its own and promises more free money for the money changers on WS...you must be a government worker or work for a crony capitalist company yourself, or you would not be talking this nonsense...you need to wise up!.

Message.Title: Dipshidiot was right!!
Message.Msg: "Rep. Corrine Brown (D-Fla.) on Thursday said passage of a Republican farm bill that excludes a reauthorized food stamp program shows that Republicans don't care about "the 47 percent." "Mitt Romney was right, you all do not care about the 47 percent. Shame on you!" she yelled as she pointed to the Republican side of the House. Earlier actions by Brown had some Republicans suggesting they'd ask for her remarks to be stricken from the record. After Brown cried "shame on Republicans" during closing debate on the farm bill, Rep. Rob Woodall (R-Ga.) initially asked to stop the proceedings and possibly have her words taken from the record. Woodall then withdrew that request."

Raw Story Rep. Louie Gohmert (R-TX) on Thursday objected over and over again in order to keep statements out of the congressional record that accused Republicans of hurting working families by taking food stamps out of the farm bill. Before a vote could be taken on the Republican farm bill that drops the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) — or food stamps — Democrats attempted to voice their unhappiness by inserting statements into the record. “Mr. Speaker, I ask unanimous consent to revise and extend my remarks in strong opposition to the farm bill rule and the underlying bill because it will increase hunger in America,” Rep. Suzanne Bonamici (D-OR) said. Although requests to “revise and extend” remarks are routine, Gohmert immediate shouted, “Objection!”

Message.Title: Option Question for Board Members.
Message.Msg: I sold some F 2015 options today and noticed they had very little "Time" value even though they expired in Jan 2015. I also noticed E-Trade options also carried little time value. Is this what happens when stocks get toppy? Just started to use options this year but find them as illogical as stocks sometimes...lol

Message.Title: All the OLB's down today
Message.Msg: First, they were all a bit toppy going into earnings. Secondly, the FED continued buys, will keep interest rates lower. The thought of higher interest rates were giving the OLB's a boost.
